title: Kim Won-seok
text:
Kim Won-seok () is a South Korean <a href="television%20director">television director</a>. He directed "<a href="Sungkyunkwan%20Scandal">Sungkyunkwan Scandal</a>" (2010), "<a href="Monstar%20%28TV%20series%29">Monstar</a>" (2013), "<a href="Misaeng%20%28TV%20series%29">Misaeng</a>" (2014), "<a href="Signal%20%28South%20Korean%20TV%20series%29">Signal</a>" (2016), "<a href="My%20Mister">My Mister</a>" (2018) and "<a href="Arthdal%20Chronicles">Arthdal Chronicles</a>" (2019).
Career.
Kim Won-seok began his television career in 2001 as an <a href="assistant%20director">assistant director</a> for the <a href="Korean%20Broadcasting%20System">Korean Broadcasting System</a> (KBS) network. He was promoted to <a href="second%20unit">second unit</a> director in 2005, and honed his skills on series of diverse genres. He also directed two episodes for the single-episode anthology "<a href="Drama%20City">Drama City</a>" in 2007, "GOD" (which he co-wrote) and "The Dual Accounts Murder".
Kim's first <a href="Korean%20drama">television drama series</a> as the head <a href="television%20director">production director</a> was "fusion" <a href="historical%20drama">historical drama</a> "<a href="Sungkyunkwan%20Scandal">Sungkyunkwan Scandal</a>" in 2010. Based on <a href="Jung%20Eun-gwol">Jung Eun-gwol</a>'s bestselling 2007 novel "The Lives of Sungkyunkwan Confucian Scholars", it depicted the friendship and love that develops between four classmates (including a girl disguised as a boy) attending <a href="Sungkyunkwan">Sungkyunkwan</a>, <a href="Joseon">Joseon</a>'s highest educational institute where no women were allowed. Despite solid but unspectacular viewership ratings in the mid-teens, "Sungkyunkwan Scandal" became a <a href="cult%20hit">cult hit</a> among younger viewers, resulting in increased popularity for its cast <a href="Park%20Min-young">Park Min-young</a>, <a href="Park%20Yoo-chun">Park Yoo-chun</a>, <a href="Yoo%20Ah-in">Yoo Ah-in</a> and <a href="Song%20Joong-ki">Song Joong-ki</a>, and several trophies at the <a href="2010%20KBS%20Drama%20Awards">2010 KBS Drama Awards</a>. Kim won Best New Television Director at the <a href="47th%20Paeksang%20Arts%20Awards">47th</a> <a href="Baeksang%20Arts%20Awards">Baeksang Arts Awards</a>, and Best Production Director at the <a href="4th%20Korea%20Drama%20Awards">4th</a> <a href="Korea%20Drama%20Awards">Korea Drama Awards</a>.
Kim left KBS and in August 2011, he signed with media conglomerate <a href="CJ%20E%26amp%3BM">CJ E&M</a>, which owns cable channels <a href="Mnet%20%28TV%20channel%29">Mnet</a> and <a href="TVN%20%28South%20Korea%29">tvN</a>. His first project post-move was a 30-minute music video for "<a href="Superstar%20K3">Superstar K3</a>" starring the <a href="reality%20show">reality show</a>'s remaining contestants, titled "Superstar K3: The Beginning". Then inspired by the American show "<a href="Glee%20%28TV%20series%29">Glee</a>", Kim directed Mnet's first-ever musical drama, "<a href="Monstar%20%28TV%20series%29">Monstar</a>" in 2013. It was Kim's third time to collaborate with screenwriter Kim Tae-hee (after "The Dual Accounts Murder" and "Sungkyunkwan Scandal"). Auditions were held, and Kim cast rookie actress <a href="Ha%20Yeon-soo">Ha Yeon-soo</a>, <a href="K-pop">K-pop</a> <a href="Korean%20pop%20idol">singer</a> <a href="Yong%20Jun-hyung">Yong Jun-hyung</a> and stage actor <a href="Kang%20Ha-neul">Kang Ha-neul</a> in the lead roles.
When tvN announced that Kim would next adapt <a href="Yoon%20Tae-ho">Yoon Tae-ho</a>'s <a href="webtoon">webtoon</a> "<a href="Misaeng%20%28manhwa%29">Misaeng</a>" (lit. "Incomplete Life") about a former <a href="go%20%28game%29">baduk</a> player who becomes an office <a href="temporary%20work">temp worker</a> at a trading company, it became one of the most anticipated Korean TV series of 2014. The workplace dramedy "<a href="Misaeng%20%28TV%20series%29">Misaeng</a>" had no A-list stars (its cast was led by <a href="Yim%20Si-wan">Yim Si-wan</a> and <a href="Lee%20Sung-min%20%28actor%29">Lee Sung-min</a>), but it struck a chord among viewers and critics, unexpectedly becoming a huge ratings hit for cable and a pop culture phenomenon. Kim said, "As cartoonist Yoon said he had rejected every offer from major broadcasters who wanted to dramatize his cartoon because they wanted to insert a love-hate relationship as dramatic devices for TV version. But I told him we wouldn't do that. We, instead, focused more on life of ordinary people like the original cartoon to give glimpse at office life. [...] I wanted to make a realistic drama about ordinary people." "Misaeng" won the Grand Prize (Daesang) at the 9th Cable TV Broadcasting Awards, while Kim won Best Television Director at the <a href="51st%20Paeksang%20Arts%20Awards">51st Baeksang Arts Awards</a>, beating nominees from terrestrial channels.
Kim next cast <a href="Lee%20Je-hoon">Lee Je-hoon</a>, <a href="Kim%20Hye-soo">Kim Hye-soo</a> and <a href="Cho%20Jin-woong">Cho Jin-woong</a> in "<a href="Signal%20%28South%20Korean%20TV%20series%29">Signal</a>", based on the <a href="Hwaseong%20serial%20murders">real-life unsolved serial rape-murders</a> of ten women in the city of <a href="Hwaseong%2C%20Gyeonggi">Hwaseong</a> between 1986 and 1991 (the case also inspired "<a href="Memories%20of%20Murder">Memories of Murder</a>" and "<a href="Gap-dong">Gap-dong</a>"). In "<a href="Signal%20%28South%20Korean%20TV%20series%29">Signal</a>", detectives from the present and the past communicate across time and space through a <a href="two-way%20radio">two-way radio</a> to solve the crimes. The series was a critical and commercial success, and is currently the second highest-rated drama in Korean cable television history. "Signal" won several awards from award-giving bodies including Best Drama at the <a href="52nd%20Paeksang%20Arts%20Awards">52nd Baeksang Arts Awards</a>.
From 2016 to 2019, Kim was under <a href="Studio%20Dragon">Studio Dragon</a>, the production company spun off from CJ E&M. In December 2019, he resigned from the company due to personal reasons.
In January 2020, "<a href="The%20JoongAng%20Ilbo">The JoongAng Ilbo</a>" published an exclusive report that stated Kim has joined <a href="Kakao%20M">Kakao M</a>'s soon-to-be-launched new drama production subsidiary to be led by former Studio Dragon and CJ E&M executive Park Ho-sik. Seven months later, the company, Baram Pictures, was officially launched.
